entry.title: Re: Crystal Reports application pool crashes 5011, 1000 W...
entry.content:
SP 33 is quite old, upgrade to SP 38, SAP only supports the latest SP, you can get it from here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354091173.html?locale=en-US

Also, CR for VS only supports 4.7 and 4.8 Framework, 4.5 is quite old and no longer supported by Microsoft.

Check the CR for VS Platform supported here:

https://www.sap.com/documents/2016/06/f871031e-757c-0010-82c7-eda71af511fa.html

Those errors are being generated by IIS, not CR error codes.

A quick Google search for IIS errors suggested this:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/466375/was-event-id-5011

IIS Error 5011, reported as a Warning in the System Event Log with the source "Microsoft-Windows-WAS" (Windows Process Activation Service), indicates that an application pool process suffered a fatal communication error with WAS. This typically leads to the application pool crashing or restarting.
 
 
Common Causes:
 
 
  • Resource Exhaustion:
    Insufficient CPU, memory, or disk resources can cause the application pool process to become unresponsive and lose communication with WAS.
  • Third-Party Software Conflicts:
    Backup agents, antivirus software, or other third-party applications can interfere with IIS processes and cause crashes.
  • Expired Certificates:
    In Exchange Server environments, an expired OAuth certificate can lead to application pool crashes.
  • Application Pool Configuration Issues:
    Incorrect identity settings for the application pool or other misconfigurations can cause instability.
  • Unhandled Exceptions or Crashes within the Application:
    Errors within the web application itself (e.g., unhandled exceptions, memory leaks, or native code issues) can lead to the process crashing.
     
  •  
Troubleshooting Steps:
 
 
  • Check Event Viewer:
    Examine the System and Application logs in Event Viewer for Event ID 5011 and any related events (e.g., 15004-15007) that might provide more specific error details or clues about the cause.
  • Monitor Resource Utilization:
    Use Performance Monitor or Process Explorer to track CPU, memory, and disk usage at the time of the crashes to identify potential resource bottlenecks.
  • Recycle the Application Pool:
    As a temporary measure, recycle the affected application pool from IIS Manager to see if it stabilizes the service.
  • Review Application Pool Identity:
    Verify the identity configured for the application pool in IIS Manager and ensure it has the necessary permissions. Re-applying the identity settings can sometimes resolve issues.
  • Check for Third-Party Software Conflicts:
    Temporarily disable or uninstall any recently installed backup or antivirus software to see if it resolves the issue.
  • Verify Certificates:
    If applicable (e.g., Exchange Server), check the validity of any relevant certificates, such as the OAuth certificate.
  • Analyze Crash Dumps:
    If the issue persists and involves consistent crashes, consider configuring IIS to generate crash dumps and analyze them with tools like Windbg to identify the root cause within the application or its dependencies.

Pranshul

entry.title: Re: Don't have access to download software
entry.content:
Hi Pranshul, 

In order to download software from the Software Center, the S-user must have the 'Software Download' authorization. However, your S-user currently lacks the necessary authorization.

Typically, you would need to reach out to one of the administrators listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me to obtain the required authorization. For more detailed information on S-user authorizations, please refer to the Authorization Concept

If you have any questions or need further assistance, please feel free to contact us.

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Applying 'Techncial User Propagation' to API Management
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

In the previous blog, we explored how technical user propagation works in SAP Integration Suite / Cloud Integration using the OData V2, SOAP, and HTTP receiver adapters. In this installment, we turn our attention to API Management, where the on-premise proxy component plays a crucial role in securely bridging cloud-hosted APIs with on-premise systems. Much like Cloud Integration, the question of propagating a fixed technical identity comes up frequently here ‚Äî but the mechanisms and configuration steps differ.

2. Quick recap on on-premise connectivity in API Management:

Before diving deeper, let‚Äôs briefly review how API Management handles connectivity to on-premise systems. Within the API Provider settings, API Management supports the concept of Principal Propagation. This means that when a request is forwarded to an on-premise system, the expectation is that a valid user session (or principal) already exists ‚Äî typically established via mechanisms such as SSO / token exchange.

Under the hood, the On-premise proxy component in API Management uses the BTP Destination as the connectivity anchor. The authenticated user session is propagated to this destination, which in turn leverages the Cloud Connector to securely tunnel the call into the corporate network. Finally, at the backend system level, the X.509 certificate mechanism comes into play, mapping the propagated principal to the appropriate backend user. We described this process in our previous blog.

3. Concrete example ‚Äì Entra ID & token exchange:

In practice, many customers authenticate users against Identity Provider systems such as Entra ID (formerly Azure AD). In this flow, Entra ID issues a JWT token where the user subject (often the user‚Äôs email ID) is included as a claim. This JWT is then presented to API Management, which, after an optional verification step, in turn exchanges it with XSUAA using the OAuth2 SAML Assertion flow. The result is an XSUAA-issued token that the on-premise proxy component in API Management can securely propagate downstream. This pattern is widely adopted and serves as the backbone of many user-centric API Management scenarios.

Note: There are many excellent SAP Community blogs that go into great detail about this token handshake and its variants. To keep our focus sharp, we won‚Äôt recap those here ‚Äî instead, we‚Äôll stay aligned with the specific objective of this blog: exploring how technical user propagation scenarios can be addressed in API Management‚Äôs On-Premise proxy component.

4. From user sessions to technical credentials:

While the model described above works seamlessly for user-centric flows, many integration patterns require a fixed technical credential instead. This is where customers start looking for approaches similar to the one we highlighted in Cloud Integration, where technical user propagation can be achieved by leveraging the 'SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication' header. With API Management‚Äôs on-premise proxy component, patterns are available to achieve secure technical identity propagation, which differ slightly from the one we highlighted for Cloud Integration.

5. Usage scenarios with API Management:

To make this blog post engaging, we would like to introduce multiple patterns of usage, since there is no single ‚Äúgold standard‚Äù  for implementing authentication in API Management. The right choice depends on the system landscape, security requirements, and integration goals. Below, we outline a few practical scenarios that illustrate different approaches. You are free to adjust the scenario based on your security needs:

1. JWT Bearer Token injection (Client credentials authentication):

In this scenario, the client is responsible for obtaining an access token itself. This typically involves the client exchanging its client credentials of API Management's on-premise proxy component for a JWT access token and presenting it as part of the API call. API Management then processes this token and propagates the corresponding identity further downstream through the destination, Cloud Connector, and finally to the backend.

Note: While this approach is relatively straightforward, it places the responsibility of managing OAuth credentials and tokens directly on the client. Therefore, it should not be relied upon as the sole security mechanism. It is strongly recommended to validate the JWT on the API Management layer (or downstream) and ensure that it contains the expected claims (such as issuer, audience, scope, or custom claims like the target client_id) before granting access. This ensures that the token has not only been issued by BTP's XSUAA  but also carries the correct authorization context for your APIs.

Pre-requisite(s):

Make sure that you have created a service instance of the 'API Management, API portal'  service with the 'on-premise-connectivity' service plan.

2. API Key injection (Credential abstraction for clients):

In this setup, the client application supplies an API Key when calling API Management in addition to any other security mechanism. Behind the scenes, the API Proxy is configured to exchange fixed technical credentials with the Identity Provider (BTP XSUAA) to obtain an access token. This approach helps ensure that the sensitive technical credentials ‚Äî the ones that need to be propagated ‚Äî remain hidden from the client, thereby strengthening security.

To make matters more interesting, in our walkthrough, we will not rely on a basic client credentials grant type. Instead, we will demonstrate a certificate-based token exchange, where API Management presents a client certificate to XSUAA (via OAuth2 with mutual TLS) to obtain the token. This pattern is increasingly popular in enterprise landscapes because it provides stronger binding between client identity and issued tokens (RFC 8705), without ever exposing the client secret, while still abstracting the complexity from the consuming client.

Pre-requisite(s):

a) Ensure that the Developer Hub is enabled and that you can create product subscriptions.

b) Ensure you have a service key enabled for X.509 certificate authentication. Copy the generated client_id. You can follow this guide to set it up, and then refer to step 3.3 in our previous article to create a PFX/P12 file that bundles the certificate and key together.

c) Ensure that the PFX file is uploaded to a keystore from the 'Certificates' section.

3. Client Certificate-based Authentication:

In this scenario, the consuming client application presents an external client certificate directly to the API Management runtime when invoking an API. The API Management host validates the certificate against its trust store and, based on pre-configured certificate-to-credential mapping, resolves the call to a fixed technical credential.

This design is particularly useful in system-to-system integrations where client identities are represented by certificates instead of (/in addition to) tokens or API Keys, as the certificate itself acts as the authentication factor. Internally, the mapped technical user is then propagated through to the BTP Destination, Cloud Connector, and ultimately to the backend system using the same mechanisms as in the earlier scenarios.

Note: This approach is especially appealing when clients cannot (or should not) handle OAuth flows, but are capable of securely storing and presenting a client certificate. However, it requires careful lifecycle management of certificates (renewal, rotation, and trust configuration) to ensure uninterrupted connectivity.

Pre-requisite(s):

  1. Make sure you are configured for certificate-based authentication. You can then manage your clients‚Äô certificate chains in the Trust Store as a convenient self-service feature.
  2.  Ensure you can read the 'ConnectionProperties' and 'ClientProperties' property variables. You will need to create an operations ticket to do so. 

Let‚Äôs examine each of these scenarios in detail. Please note that this is not a step-by-step guide; rather, we will focus on highlighting only the key steps.

6. Scenario#1 (Client credentials Authentication) - API Provider and Proxy configurations:

Let‚Äôs review the essential API Provider and Proxy configurations required to enable propagation of the 'SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication' header.

1. Create an Extract Variable policy like so (typically on the 'PreFlow' step) to extract the JWT token from the Authorization request and store it in a variable to be referenced later.

<!-- Extract content from the request or response messages, including headers, URI paths, JSON/XML payloads, form parameters, and query parameters -->
<ExtractVariables async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="false" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Header name="Authorization">
        <Pattern ignoreCase="true">Bearer {sapapim.jwt}</Pattern>
    </Header>
    <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<Source>request</Source>
</ExtractVariables>

2. After this step, use a Verify JWT policy to verify the signatures on the JWT as well as any standard and custom claims. Follow this blog series to learn more about JWT verification capabilities.

<!-- Verify JWT TOken -->
<VerifyJWT async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Algorithm>RS256</Algorithm>
    <Source>sapapim.jwt</Source>
    <PublicKey>
            <Value ref="jwt.publickey"/>
    </PublicKey>
    <Subject ref="apim.subject"/>
    <Issuer ref="apim.issuer"/>
    <Audience ref="apim.issuer"/>
    <AdditionalClaims>
    </AdditionalClaims>
</VerifyJWT>

3. Next, create an AssignMessage policy like so to inject the 'SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication' header with the variable captured from the previous step, and make sure to remove the 'Authorization' header.

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Remove>
		<Headers>
		     <Header name="Authorization"></Header>
		</Headers>
	</Remove>
	<Set>
		<Headers>
		     <Header name="SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication">Bearer {sapapim.accessToken}</Header>
		</Headers>
	</Set> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request">request</AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 4. Finally, ensure that the API Provider‚Äôs authentication setting is configured as None rather than Principal Propagation. This is the very configuration we applied for the SOAP Adapter scenario discussed in the previous blog post.

5. Let's get down to testing now. The first step would be to get an access token from the authorization server's (XSUAA) token endpoint.

curl --location --request POST 'https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token' \
  --header 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
  --user '<client_id>:<client_secret>' \
  --data-urlencode 'grant_type=client_credentials'

6. Copy the access token from the result of the call above and invoke the API Proxy by presenting the Bearer token in the Authorization header.

curl --location --request GET 'https://<apim_base_url>/<your_api_path>' \
  --header "Authorization: Bearer <access_token>"

‚úÖ Assuming that the rest of your configurations are intact, the call should complete successfully and return the expected backend records.

7. To validate the token handshake and X.509 certificate generation, refer to the verification steps detailed in Step 4.1 in our linked blog post.

7. Scenario#2 (APIKey injection) - Proxy configuration:

In this scenario, the client credentials will not be exposed directly to the client. Instead, we inject the required client_id as a custom attribute within the Product Subscription. During runtime, this identifier is dynamically retrieved via a policy and used to obtain an access token from the authorization server

1. Log in to your Developer Hub, create a product subscription for your target API. Navigate to the Custom Attribute tab and create an attribute called 'x_client_id' and place the client_id copied from step 2.b. as the Value. 

2. You may choose to follow the same workflow demonstrated in Scenario 1. In addition, an important step is to configure the Verify API Key policy, for example, in the PreFlow segment.

 <!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey'/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

3. Next, add an AccessEntity policy to get hold of a reference to the 'application's' attributes.

<!-- this policy can be used to retrieve all details of an entity(application, API Product, company, company developer, consumer key and developer) -->
<AccessEntity async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<!-- the name of the type of entity to be retrieved -->
	<EntityType value="app"/>
	<!-- The value that identifies the specific entity whose profile should be retrieved. The ref attribute identifies the variable that provides the source of the identifier. 
	The type identifies the EntityType populated by the referenced variable -->
	<EntityIdentifier ref="request.header.apikey" type="consumerkey"/>
</AccessEntity>

4. Then add an ExtractVariable policy to parse and extract the value of the custom attribute defined in the previous step.

<!-- Extract content from the request or response messages, including headers, URI paths, JSON/XML payloads, form parameters, and query parameters -->
<ExtractVariables async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<!-- the source variable which should be parsed -->
	<Source>AccessEntity.name-of-the-AccessEntity-policy-here</Source>
	<!-- Specifies the XML-formatted message from which the value of the variable will be extracted -->
	<XMLPayload>
    	<!-- Specifies variable to which the extracted value will be assigned -->
    	<Variable name="x-client-id" type="string">
    		<!-- Specifies the XPath defined for the variable -->
    		<XPath>/App/Attributes/Attribute[Name='x_client_id']/Value/text()</XPath>
   	    </Variable>
	</XMLPayload>
</ExtractVariables>

5. After this step, we add a small script to construct the URL-encoded form payload in preparation for the token retrieval step. Notice that we have not used the client secret attribute at all. 

function getFormElement(name,value){
    return name + "=" + encodeURIComponent(value);
}

function createOAuthRequest(){
    return getFormElement("grant_type","client_credentials")
                + "&" + getFormElement("client_id", context.getVariable("x-client-id")) ;
}

context.setVariable("sapapim.tokenRequest", createOAuthRequest());

6. We will follow this up with a ServiceCallout policy to make a POST request to the '.cert...' token endpoint. Notice that we are attaching the certificate of the service key retrieved in step 2.c. by referencing it from the keystore.

<ServiceCallout async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Request clearPayload="true">
        <Set>
            <Payload contentType="application/x-www-form-urlencoded">{sapapim.tokenRequest}</Payload>
            <Verb>POST</Verb>
        </Set>
        <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
    </Request>
    <Response>sapapim.tokenResponse</Response>
    <Timeout>30000</Timeout>
    <HTTPTargetConnection>
        <URL>https://<tenant-dentifier>.authentication.cert.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token</URL>
        <SSLInfo> 
                 <Enabled>true</Enabled> 
                <ClientAuthEnabled>true</ClientAuthEnabled> 
                <KeyStore>KEYSTORE-NAME-GOES-HERE</KeyStore> 
                <KeyAlias>CERTIFICATE-NAME-GOES-HERE</KeyAlias> 
        </SSLInfo>
    </HTTPTargetConnection>
</ServiceCallout>

7. Finally, retrieve the access token and attach it to the SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication header, as demonstrated in step 3 of scenario 1.

8. To test this setup, modify the curl command from scenario 1 to add the APIKey header attribute, like so:

curl --location --request GET 'https://<apim_base_url>/<your_api_path>' \ 
--header "APIKey: <your_api_key>"

8. Scenario#3 (Client certificate-based authentication) - Proxy configuration:

The critical security step in this scenario is that the client presents its certificate, which API Management validates against the trusted certificates stored in its Trust Store. This validation ensures that only clients with a recognized and trusted certificate can establish communication, thereby guaranteeing both authenticity and trust in the interaction.

When the 'ConnectionProperties' and 'ClientProperties' attributes are enabled, as described in the prerequisites section, you can also access key certificate details such as the Issuer DN and Client CN. For this scenario, we assume that the API Administrator maintains an access control list mapping a predefined set of certificate Common Names to unique client_ids. This ensures that the technical identifier is propagated only when a matching client certificate is presented. 

Let's set this up.

1. Create a Key Value Map and maintain a table mapping the common name of the client to the designated client_id. 

2. Construct a KeyValueMapOperations policy that dynamically retrieves the 'tls.client.s.dn' property from the presented certificate, looks up the Key Value Map created in the above step, and assigns the value of the client_id to a variable called 'x_client_id'. 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<KeyValueMapOperations mapIdentifier="TechnicalAuthenticationMap" async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="false" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Get assignTo="x_client_id" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter ref ="tls.client.s.dn"/>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Scope>environment</Scope>
</KeyValueMapOperations>

3. Repeat steps 5, 6, and 7 from Scenario 2 to generate an access token and assign it to the target header.

4. To test the invocation, adjust the curl command to pass the client certificate

curl --location --request GET 'https://<apim_base_url>/<your_api_path>' \
  --header "Authorization: Bearer <access_token>" \
  --header "APIKey: <your_api_key>" \
  --cert <path_to_certificate>.pfx --cert-type P12 --pass <pfx_password>

üëèCongratulations on getting this far!

9. Summary:

The three API Management scenarios illustrate different approaches for technical user propagation using the SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication header. In the first approach, the client directly provides credentials to obtain an access token, exposing sensitive information. The second approach leverages API Management to propagate technical credentials internally, keeping them hidden from the client and simplifying integration. The third approach uses mutual TLS and X.509 certificates to securely propagate the technical user identity from API Management through the API Provider to the backend system, ensuring end-to-end authentication without exposing internal credentials.

entry.title: Re: Payment Block not working in FB60 even though Manual...

Hello,

Please refer to this blog for some interesting background information: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/payment-block/ba-p/13295215

When posting an invoice through FB60 nothing should be blocked. The payment block should only block incoming or outgoing payments.
If the payment block is set on account level, there is no need to block individual items.

Please check what happens if you try to run a payment run (F110) for the vendor with the payment block.

Best Regards,
Henk Hoogerbrug

entry.title: Re: canada tax rates
entry.content:
Possible causes could be

  • MW5 might be marked as statistical in the tax procedure (transaction OBYZ). If a condition is statistical, it won‚Äôt allow rate entry in FTXP.
  • The condition type MW5 may not have a valid access sequence or the condition record may be locked by another user/session.

Follow the below steps to update the tax rate


  • Go to transaction OBYZ, select your Canadian tax procedure (e.g., TAXCAJ). Find MW5 and ensure Statistical checkbox is not selected, Calculation type is correct (usually percentage). Condition class is set appropriately (usually class D for taxes).
  • Go to SCC4, ensure the client allows changes to cross-client customizing. If not, coordinate with your BASIS team to temporarily open it.
  • Go to transaction FTXP, select Country = CA, Tax Code = N1 or N2, enter the validity period, ppdate the MW5 rate (e.g., 5.00%). Save the changes.

Additionally,

  • If you're using jurisdiction-based tax, ensure the jurisdiction codes are correctly mapped and active
  • For input tax codes, verify that MW5 is assigned to the correct account key (e.g., VST)
  • If you're using condition-based tax determination, check the access sequence and condition records via VK13

entry.title: Re: Automated tender/RFP management for supplier - multin...
entry.content: SAP Ariba will handle as a supplier portal, and is great for identification / discovery of tenders/RFPs for suppliers. But it won't necessarily help with evaluation and responding to tenders/RFPs. There's numerous RFP response Software that work in portal such as SAP Ariba. Those include AutoRFP, Responsive, Loopio etc. For submitting RFPs, you may interact with SAP Ariba via the portal, but many RFPs will come in word doc/excel. In that case your RFP automation software (e.g. AutoRFP.ai etc mentioned above) will help with auto fill of RFP requirements based on your past RFPs and documentation.

entry.title: Re: Payment Block not working in FB60 even though Manual...
entry.content:
While the blog shared here, gives a comprehensive overview of payment block types, their configuration, and how they behave across different transactions ‚Äî especially in payment execution and invoice verification, you need to understand why FB60 allows posting despite a vendor block, and how to enforce stricter behavior using validation or configuration.

SAP‚Äôs standard behavior is the payment block in the vendor master does not automatically transfer to the invoice during FB60 unless, you‚Äôve configured a defaulting mechanism (e.g., via OBB8), Or you manually set the block during posting. The ‚Äúmanual payments blocked‚Äù setting in customizing only affects manual payment transactions like F-53. It prevents clearing of open items with that block. It does not prevent invoice posting in FB60. So yes ‚Äî you can post invoices even if the vendor is blocked for payment. The block only affects payment execution, not invoice entry.

To default the Payment Block automatically, use transaction OBB8 to configure default payment block behavior based on Company code, Payment terms, Vendor group. This will ensure that invoices posted via FB60 inherit the block automatically.

Create a validation rule in transaction OB28 to check if vendor has block X and prevent posting unless the block is manually set on the document.

If you want stricter control, add a custom warning or error via enhancement. Train users to manually set the block during invoice entry

entry.title: How to send the notification mail for IEM once a day with the specified time
entry.content:
In FRUN system, we configured the calculating frequency of the alert for IEM(Integration & Exception Monitoring) as 1440 minutes (=24 hours) so that the alert notification is sent just once a day.
It is working fine - the alert notification is sent just once a day at around 10:50am.
Is it possible to change the time to 8:00am?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to send the notification mail for IEM once a day...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

The current design of FRUN doesn't provide the option for adjusting the time for sending an alerts.
 
The functionality you want is not provided by the SAP standard but you can try the following approach and test whether it works.
 
Basically, if the configuration of the alert was saved with a minor change (e.g. enter one more space in the alert name, etc.), it will trigger a new alert shortly thereafter.
So if you change the configuration and save it at around 7:55am, the new alert will be generated around at 8am.
However, as your configuration is already with 1440 minutes, there will be mostly data loss in the next alert instances if you just save the change around at 7:55am(or before).
 
Therefore, the better approach would be the below:

  1. Adjust the alert configuration and save it with a calculation frequency of 1265 minutes once the regular alert has been triggered at 10:55 AM.
    This adjustment will generate an additional alert shortly after the modification, capturing any new aborted jobs created between 10:55 AM and the configuration change.
    The subsequent alert will be triggered at approximately 8 AM the following day.
  2. After the alert is triggered around 8 AM the next day, revert the calculation frequency of the alert back to 1440 minutes and save the alert configuration around ~8AM (or else the next alert will be triggered 5:55am next day).
    This action will prompt one additional alert to be generated shortly thereafter capturing any new aborted jobs created between 8 AM and the configuration change.
    But this ensures all subsequent alerts are consistently triggered daily at approximately near to 8 AM.

Please test it and adjust it according your needs.

Hope above helps you.
Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: BP Relationship of Migration Object of Migration Cockpit
entry.content:
Hello @yukitsumura 

To clarify, the Customer (or Supplier) migration object in Migration Cockpit only loads the Business Partner with its roles and master data. However, it does not establish Business Partner Relationships, such as contact person links or BP‚ÄìBP connections.

In S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition 2502, there is currently no migration object available for BP Relationships. The supported options include:

Use the Business Partner Relationship API (API_BUSINESS_PARTNER_RELATIONSHIP) after migrating the BPs, or maintain the relationships manually in the Fiori apps (Maintain Business Partner, Manage Workforce).

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/resource/get_A_BusinessPartner

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.content:
Hello,

We are planning to refresh our DEV system by copying from PROD, but we need to retain ABAP version management in DEV after the refresh.

SAP Note 130906 describes a process using R3trans to export the version repository before the refresh and import it afterward to preserve versions.

However, our landscape is on RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition. We have been told that this is not possible in RISE Private Cloud due to technical restrictions.

Therefore, I would like to ask:

1. Is it indeed not possible to perform version export/import (as recommended by Note 130906) during a DEV refresh from PROD in a RISE Private Cloud environment?
2. If it's not supported, is there an alternative approach recommended to preserve development versions during a system refresh on RISE Private Cloud?
3. Are there any official SAP statements, best practices, or notes regarding version management across system refreshes in RISE Private Cloud?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Everyday issues: There is no miracle or magic. SAP HANA database needs memory.
entry.content:
last updated: 2025-08-29

Why was this blog post created?
Countless times we are faced with the fact that the cause of a system performance problem is nothing more than an insufficient amount of "working memory".

Fact: SAP HANA needs memory. In case the available "working memory" is insufficient the system won't work properly. General performance issue occurs.
Rule of thumb: the recommendation from SAP is the "tables data" should not use more than 50 % of the available memory.
One stop shop about SAP HANA memory: Collected information about memory in context of SAP HANA

How to check/detect if SAP HANA is having a memory issue?

1. SAP GUI - Transaction Code - DBACOCKPIT (Load History) - some further examples can be found here

In the case of a healthy system, a system in a calm state (e.g. out of working hours or without load) shows a constant used memory value (max. 50% of the available memory). In this case "used memory" = "tables data". When system used actively next to the "tables data" we see "working memory" also. In this case "used memory" = "tables data" + "working memory". The "working memory" increase and decrease during the system usage. We can check the memory usage easily with "Load History" option, e.g. Last 7 Days or with Custom Selections, so we can have a high level overview about the memory usage in general.

There is no room for "working memory" because "tables data" use the majority of the available memory all the time.

2. 3284834 - SQL Statement Collection: "HANA_Configuration_Minichecks" report for SAP HANA

The most general report will contain further information about the issue. Number of low memory unloads (short-term) = 226380 and Memory reclaim activity (s / day) = 26154. These are outrageously high numbers.

|M0430|Number of low memory unloads (short-term)        |      |226380                                                     |0                   |X| 2127458|
|M0435|Number of shrink unloads (short-term)            |      |0                                                          |<= 1000             | | 2127458|
|M0437|Size of unloaded columns (% / day, long-term)    |      |29.24                                                      |<= 3.00             |X| 2127458|
|M0438|Memory reclaim activity (s / day)                |      |26154                                                      |<= 1200             |X| 1999997|
|M0439|Memory reclaim maximum duration (s)              |      |57                                                         |<= 60               | | 1999997|
|M0440|Topology shared memory utilization (%)           |      |1                                                          |<= 70               | | 1977101|
|M0445|Number of OOM events (short-term)                |      |5                                                          |<= 3                |X| 1999997|
|M0446|Number of OOM events per day (mid-term)          |      |6.71                                                       |<= 3.00             |X| 1999997|
|M0447|Number of alloc. limit OOM events (long-term)    |      |47                                                         |0                   |X| 1999997|‚Äã

3. 3330262 - SQL Statement Collection: "HANA_Memory_Overview" report for SAP HANA

The report makes it easy to identify database tables that are using the majority of memory.

What are the consequences?
When the database does not have enough memory to operate, it tries to resolve the situation, it performs "unloads" and "reclaim" activities. These operations are inherent to the functionality of a healthy system, but in the case of a system constantly struggling with memory problems, they result in a constant and never-ending loop. Continuous reclaim and unload activity results in continuous resource (e.g. CPU) usage. The unloading also could affect a database table(s) that should not be removed from memory because it is in general use, meaning it will be reloaded soon again.

What is the conclusion?
There is no miracle or magic. To handle the high memory footprint you have the following options:
1. Data Management of general tables and technical tables. Reference: 3348393 - Overview of the data management process in the context of SAP HANA
2. Increase the available memory in the system.

Other article
‚úçÔ∏è Where can I find knowledge and information belongs to SAP HANA?

Useful bookmark
üîñ 2872774 ‚Äì Bookmark of Frequently Asked Questions for SAP HANA
üîñ 3311408 ‚Äì Bookmark of SQL Statement Collection reports for SAP HANA
üîñ 2658020 ‚Äì List of SAP HANA SQL Error Codes

Do you have further questions?
Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have question or observation regarding the article.
Q&A link for SAP HANA: https://answers.sap.com/tags/73554900100700000996

Contribution
If you find any missing information belongs to the topic, please let me know. I am happy to add the new content. My intention is to maintain the content continuously to keep the info up-to-date.

Release Information

entry.title: Batch Specific UoM conversion functionality not working properly after production confirmation
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

Please understand the business scenario and the configuration we have accordingly performed in SAP.

Configuration Path:
SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Batch-Specific Material Units of Measure -> Product Quantities Conversion -> Define Calculation of Base Quantity from Product Quantity

As per business scenario, material Base UoM is Meter (M) and the material comes in 5 types of Length: 4 M, 4.5 M, 5 M, 5.5 M, 6 M.

We have considered these lengths in predefined fixed batches for the material along with year & month as nomenclature, as an example ‚Äì

4.0M202508
4.50M202508
5.0M202508
5.5M202508
6.0M202508

Now, the material is produced in Pieces (PC) and production entry is booked in PC unit.

So, we have maintained PC as Batch specific UoM and for that batch characteristics BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC has been created where for each batch it‚Äôs Meter Per Piece conversion value is maintained, such that ‚Äì

4.0M202508 -> BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC = 4.0 (meter per) PC -> 4.0 M = 1PC
4.0M202508 -> BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC = 4.5 (meter per) PC -> 4.5 M = 1PC
5.0M202508 -> BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC = 5.0 (meter per) PC -> 5.0 M = 1PC
5.5M202508 -> BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC = 5.5 (meter per) PC -> 5.5 M = 1PC
6.0M202508 -> BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC = 6.0 (meter per) PC -> 6.0 M = 1PC

Now before making any production confirmation, each batch conversion value is already maintained. After GR 101 confirmation is done in Entry UoM PC, the conversion should be taken from the batch characteristics value as per batch selected. Example ‚Äì

If 4.0M202508 batch is taken for 10 PC confirmation, Entry Qty. should be 10 PC & base UoM qty should be 40 M.

If 4.5M202508 batch is taken for 10 PC confirmation, Entry Qty. should be 10 PC & base UoM qty should be 45 M.

This conversion was functioning properly initially, but all a sudden this issue started appearing that qty. conversion is not appearing properly, such that ‚Äì

If 5.5M202508 batch is taken for 10 PC confirmation base UoM qty is coming 27.5 M instead of 55 M.

This is the main critical issue.

Also parallelly, sometime entry UoM qty. in PC is getting replaced with Base UoM qty. for the material.

 

Hope the issue is well explained.
Any help or guidance on the issue will be highly appreciated.

 

Regards,

Rahul Nath
Ph - 9775675543

SAP S/4HANA  MAN Production Planning (PP) MAN Batch Management

entry.title: Re: Evaluate my Internal Tool Against Syniti ADDM ( (SAP...
entry.content:
Hi @karthik1gobburu 

Thank you for your question.

  1. Yes, Syniti ADMM can be used with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Syniti‚Äôs Advanced Data Migration and Management (ADMM) solution is officially SAP Premium Certified and recognised as SAP‚Äôs partner data migration tool of choice for all S/4HANA transition scenarios, including RISE with SAP and Public Cloud Syniti solutions accessing SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA: What is permitted?

In Public Cloud, it supports data migration by connecting to the Migration Cockpit‚Äôs HANA Cloud staging database and extracting data through OData services, often via Syniti Connect with Boomi for OData extraction skthelp.syniti.com.

  1. Can your internal migration tool replace Syniti ADMM?

From the standpoint of SAP-certified migration paths in Public Cloud, the SAP Migration Cockpit (pre-delivered by SAP) and SAP-certified partner tools (like Syniti ADMM) are the supported and endorsed approaches.

An internally developed tool cannot officially replace Syniti ADMM in Public Cloud migration scenarios because:

  • It is not SAP-certified as a solution extension.
  • Its use would fall outside SAP‚Äôs supported migration framework for Public Cloud.
  1. In What Parameters Does Syniti ADMM Add Value?

When evaluating whether your internal tool can match Syniti ADMM, consider how Syniti fares across the following key migration criteria:

  • SAP Certification and endorsement for Public Cloud migrations.
  • Connectivity options: Syniti integrates with Migration Cockpit staging DB and extracts via approved APIs (e.g., OData via Boomi)  Connecting to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Migration methodology: Syniti uses a ‚ÄúData First,‚Äù knowledge-driven approach, with automation, repeatability, and quality controls  SAP S/4HANA Data Migration
  • Support and governance: As a certified solution, Syniti is backed by SAP support and roadmap alignment.

If you will like to position your internal tool, you will need to evaluate how it aligns on these parameters, even though a full replacement of Syniti ADMM in Public Cloud is outside SAP‚Äôs supported landscape.

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Stop the Buzzword Circus: Real Impact Starts with Mobile
entry.content:
Let's be blunt. The term "digital transformation" has become a playground for charlatans, peddling expensive, multi-year projects with dismal success rates ‚Äì often exceeding 70% failure. This isn't strategic evolution; it's "Buzzword Bingo," designed to extract capital without delivering tangible value. Many organizations dive in without a clear strategy, leading to wasted resources and frustration.

Meanwhile, the cost of clinging to outdated manual processes is staggering. American employees waste over nine hours a week on data entry, costing businesses a hefty $28,500 per employee annually. This isn't just about salary; it‚Äôs about errors ‚Äì humans make 100-400 errors per 10,000 entries compared to the near-perfect accuracy of automated systems [8, 9]. These errors cascade into financial losses and operational bottlenecks.

The solution? A pragmatic approach centered on the mobile-first advantage. By leveraging smartphones and tablets for instant digital intake ‚Äì think scanning forms with intelligent document processing (IDP) ‚Äì we eliminate manual errors and unlock real "low-hanging fruit." This isn't about grand transformations; it‚Äôs about targeted digitalization that delivers immediate ROI. For example, field service apps using mobile data collection can boost efficiency and reduce errors by up to 70%. This isn't a futuristic fantasy; it‚Äôs a proven strategy for tangible results.

entry.title: Re: is there any relationship between an account assignme...
entry.content:
When you enter the account assignment category (e.g., K for cost center), SAP re-evaluates the tax code based on the access sequence defined in the tax condition type (typically TTX1).

Common Access Sequence fields are Material, Plant, Account Assignment Category, Region & Origin Country. So if your condition table includes Account Assignment Category as a key field, the system may override the PIR tax code (V3) with a new one (V1) based on the combination of material, plant, and account assignment.

To ensure that V3 (10%) remains the default tax code even after entering account assignment, you can:

1. Review and Adjust the Condition Table
Go to SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Taxes ‚Üí Define Access Sequences. Check the access sequence used by TTX1. If it includes Account Assignment Category, either remove it from the access sequence, or create a new condition record for Account Assignment Category = K with tax code V3.

2. Create Specific Condition Records
Use transaction FV11 to create tax condition records for Material + Plant + Account Assignment Category = K ‚Üí Tax Code = V3.

3. Check Tax Indicator in Material Master
Ensure the Tax Indicator for Material is set correctly in the material master (Purchasing view). This influences tax determination when PIR is not used.

A Best Practice tip is if you want consistent tax behavior regardless of account assignment, simplify your access sequence to exclude fields that cause variability (like AAC). But if you need different tax codes for different AACs, then condition records must be maintained accordingly.

entry.title: Interactive Debugging in SAP Callidus Advanced workflow
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am working with SAP Callidus (SAP Commissions) Advanced Workflow and facing difficulties with debugging options.

Currently, I am relying on logger.info statements to print variable values or outputs from methods. While this helps to some extent, it is not efficient when workflows and scripts become large and complex.

What I am looking for is something similar to the SAP ABAP/Eclipse debugger, where we could:

  • Set breakpoints in the workflow script

  • Inspect available variables, objects, classes, or methods at runtime

  • Step through the workflow execution to see what events are triggered and in what sequence

My questions are:

  1. Is there any way (official or unofficial) to perform interactive debugging with breakpoints in Callidus Advanced Workflow?

  2. Are there tools, techniques, or plugins that can make debugging easier than just using logger.info statements?

  3. How can we explore the list of available classes and methods that can be used in workflow scripting? Is there documentation or a way to introspect them?

  4. What are the best practices you recommend for troubleshooting and debugging in Advanced Workflow?

Debugging without visibility into available classes and methods is proving very challenging, so any recommendations, tips, or even workarounds would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks for your help and support.

#Advanced workflow, #Callidus

Thanks, Sateesh
